entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French poisun drink, potion, poison, from Latin potion-, potio drink potion

def.dt: :a substance that through its chemical action usually kills, injures, or impairs an organism
:something destructive or harmful
:an object of aversion or abhorrence
:a substance that inhibits the activity of another substance or the course of a reaction or process a catalyst poison
:to injure or kill with poison
:to treat, taint, or impregnate with or as if with poison
:to exert a baneful influence on :corrupt poisoned their minds
:to inhibit the activity, course, or occurrence of on the night when he poisoned my rest Charles Dickens
:poisonous venomous a poison plant a poison tongue
:impregnated with poison :poisoned a poison arrow

:any of several small brightly colored frogs (family Dendrobatidae) of tropical Central and South America that produce poisonous secretions sometimes used by native peoples to poison dart or arrow tips called also poison arrow frog
:a poisonous gas or a liquid or a solid giving off poisonous vapors designed (as in chemical warfare) to kill, injure, or disable by inhalation or contact
:a large European biennial poisonous herb (Conium maculatum) of the carrot family that is naturalized in the United States and has finely divided leaves and small white flowers compare water hemlock

:a climbing plant (Toxicodendron radicans syn. Rhus radicans) of the cashew family that is especially common in the eastern and central United States, that has ternate leaves, greenish flowers, and white berries, and that produces an acutely irritating oil causing a usually intensely itching skin rash
:any of several plants closely related to poison ivy
:a skin rash caused by poison ivy
:any of several plants related to poison ivy and producing an oil with similar irritating properties: as
:a bushy plant (Toxicodendron diversilobum syn. Rhus diversiloba) of the Pacific coast
:a bushy plant (Toxicodendron toxicarium syn. Rhus toxicodendron) chiefly of the southeastern U.S.
:poison ivy 1a
:written with malice and spite and usually anonymously a poison–pen letter
:a financial tactic or provision used by a company to make an unwanted takeover prohibitively expensive or less desirable
